docAbstract: The Department proposes to rescind portions of its tip regulations issued pursuant to the FLSA that impose restrictions on employers that pay a direct cash wage of at least the full Federal minimum wage and do not claim a tip credit against their minimum wage obligations.

text:
,

I oppose the proposed Tip Regulations Under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) regulation (RIN: 1235-AA21).

This rule would go against decades of federal and state law and precedent safeguarding tips as the property of the workers who receive them, by allowing employers to take control of their employees tips. The Fair Labor Standards Act was amended in 1974 to clarify that tips are to be retained by the employee except when a valid tip pooling arrangement is in place. In 2011, the DOL issued new regulations that reinforced the FLSA and over 40 years of custom and practice by the DOL and state agencies, affirming that tips are always the property of the employee (29 C.F.R. 531.52).

If adopted, this regulation would force a vulnerable workforce further into poverty, economic instability, and vulnerability to harassment and assault.

I urge the Department of Labor to withdraw this proposed rule.

text:
The U.S. Department of Agriculture's job is to assure consumers that organically produced products meet a consistent and uniform standard. Access to outdoors means just that--access to the outdoors. I am writing today to express my strong opposition to the proposed withdrawal of the Organic Livestock and Poultry Practices final rule. I urge you to reconsider this baseless move to weaken the USDA Organic seal. This action is an assault on organic farmers, businesses, and consumers everywhere.

I rely on a strong USDA Organic seal to know that what I am purchasing is backed by a standard that I can trust. I am willing to put my money where my mouth is, but I expect products bearing the USDA Organic seal to meet rigorous standards.

It's important to me to know that the same strong standard applies to all organic products regardless of where I buy them. I understand that organic farmers and businesses of all types and sizes overwhelmingly support the final rule, and I find it outrageous that you are making this move to withdraw the rule against their recommendation. The withdrawal endorses a few businesses that deny animals access the outdoors and ignores the millions of consumers who rightly equate animals going outside with the organic label.

I want to support the organic farmers and businesses who share my values, but you are putting that in jeopardy. I urge you to please implement the final rule.

text:
It is VERY important to me as a consumer to know what the standards are for the treatment of animals in the meat, poultry, dairy and egg products that I buy. The USDA organic label is of little value if it does not assume me that the products I am buying were produced with animal raising and treating practices that I can support with a good conscience. There is no point in paying premium prices for USDA organic certified products if the USDA if this is not the case.

The community of consumers who buys organic products also cares about animal welfare, and we are not stupid. If we are not assured of decent animal raising practices, we will boycott the USDA brand and encourage everyone else to do so too, and rely on private brands.

We are paying attention. Make the USDA Organic label one we turn to, instead of one we turn away from.

Dear Labor Board,

I am saddened that it is even being proposed that employers receive tip money given to well deserving employees for their services. Employers are already paying a wage that no person could effectively live on. WHY EXACTLY SHOULD EMPLOYERS BE ENTITLED TO TIP MONEY EARNED BY GOOD SERVICE FROM ITS EMPLOYEES ANYWAY? These employees count on these tips and would not work at these establishments without them unless a huge wage increase was given. Believe me when I say I have first hand experience in exactly what its like to depend on tip money in Place of a decent wage n hour. My wife worked at Applebees as a bartender for 15 years. The tip money was how she could justify working there. The pay checks were a joke. Most of the time she didnt even receive a check due to taxes on the tip money she claimed.

All who propose this rule should be ashamed especially the Labor Board that should be protecting workers rights along with employers. I

docAbstract: The Department proposes to rescind portions of its tip regulations issued pursuant to the FLSA that impose restrictions on employers that pay a direct cash wage of at least the full Federal minimum wage and do not claim a tip credit against their minimum wage obligations.

text:
,

I oppose the proposed rule (RIN: 1235-AA21). It would go against decades of federal and state law and precedent safeguarding tips as the property of the workers who receive them, by allowing employers to take control of their employees tips.

The Fair Labor Standards Act was amended in 1974 to clarify that tips are to be retained by the employee except when a valid tip pooling arrangement is in place.

In 2011, the DOL issued new regulations to reinforce the FLSA and over 40 years of custom and practice by the DOL and state agencies, affirming that tips are always the property of the employee (29 C.F.R. 531.52).

If adopted, this regulation would force a vulnerable workforce further into poverty, economic instability, and vulnerability to harassment and assault.

I urge the Department of Labor to withdraw this proposed rule.

text:
The USDA's refusal to implement the Organic Livestock and Poultry Practices (OLPP) rule, the culmination of over a decade of work aimed at improving organic standards, is shameful. Although the "organic" label evokes an image of high-level animal welfare, current standards are alarmingly vague or nonexistent. The organics industry is in favor of the rule, with the Organic Trade Association fighting for implementation. The USDA is being led around by a handful of Big Ag corporations and ignoring consumers, farmers, and over 60 million animals.

These standards and certification are entirely within the USDA's jurisdiction. In a time when we are learning more about the benefits of raising animals properly and marketplace demand for this, it is unacceptable that the USDA is not taking a stand for organic farmers.

text:
The U.S. Department of Agriculture's job is to assure consumers that organically produced products meet a consistent and uniform standard. Access to outdoors means just that--access to the outdoors. I am writing today to express my strong opposition to the proposed withdrawal of the Organic Livestock and Poultry Practices final rule. I urge you to reconsider this baseless move to weaken the USDA Organic seal. This action is an assault on organic farmers, businesses, and consumers everywhere.

I rely on a strong USDA Organic seal to know that what I am purchasing is backed by a standard that I can trust. I am willing to put my money where my mouth is, but I expect products bearing the USDA Organic seal to meet rigorous standards.

It's important to me to know that the same strong standard applies to all organic products regardless of where I buy them. I understand that organic farmers and businesses of all types and sizes overwhelmingly support the final rule, and I find it outrageous that you are making this move to withdraw the rule against their recommendation. The withdrawal endorses a few businesses that deny animals access the outdoors and ignores the millions of consumers who rightly equate animals going outside with the organic label.

I want to support the organic farmers and businesses who share my values, but you are putting that in jeopardy. I urge you to please implement the final rule.

I oppose the proposed Tip Regulations Under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) regulation (RIN: 1235-AA21).

This rule would go against decades of federal and state law and precedent safeguarding tips as the property of the workers who receive them, by allowing employers to take control of their employees tips. The Fair Labor Standards Act was amended in 1974 to clarify that tips are to be retained by the employee except when a valid tip pooling arrangement is in place. In 2011, the DOL issued new regulations that reinforced the FLSA and over 40 years of custom and practice by the DOL and state agencies, affirming that tips are always the property of the employee (29 C.F.R. 531.52).

If adopted, this regulation would force a vulnerable workforce further into poverty, economic instability, and vulnerability to harassment and assault.

I urge the Department of Labor to withdraw this proposed rule.

Kathy OBrien
cooperhenry00@gmail.com
P.mo. Box 2424
Redway, California 95560

text:
The U.S. Department of Agriculture's job is to assure consumers that organically produced products meet a consistent and uniform standard. Access to outdoors means just that--access to the outdoors. I am writing today to express my strong opposition to the proposed withdrawal of the Organic Livestock and Poultry Practices final rule. I urge you to reconsider this baseless move to weaken the USDA Organic seal. This action is an assault on organic farmers, businesses, and consumers everywhere.

I rely on a strong USDA Organic seal to know that what I am purchasing is backed by a standard that I can trust. I am willing to put my money where my mouth is, but I expect products bearing the USDA Organic seal to meet rigorous standards.

It's important to me to know that the same strong standard applies to all organic products regardless of where I buy them. I understand that organic farmers and businesses of all types and sizes overwhelmingly support the final rule, and I find it outrageous that you are making this move to withdraw the rule against their recommendation. The withdrawal endorses a few businesses that deny animals access the outdoors and ignores the millions of consumers who rightly equate animals going outside with the organic label.

I want to support the organic farmers and businesses who share my values, but you are putting that in jeopardy. I urge you to please implement the final rule.

docAbstract: NMFS would promulgate a new rule to implement Amendment 47 to the Fishery Management Plan for the Reef Fish Resources of the Gulf of Mexico. The amendment would establish a proxy for the estimate of the stock maximum sustainable yield (MSY) and the rule would revise the stock annual catch limit (ACL). The the yield when fishing to a mortality rate corresponding to 30% spawning potential ratio (F30%SPR) would be the established proxy. The ACL for vermilion snapper stock would decrease for the years 2017-2021 from 3.42 million pounds whole weight to 3.11 million pounds whole weight.

docAbstract: NMFS would promulgate a new rule to implement Amendment 47 to the Fishery Management Plan for the Reef Fish Resources of the Gulf of Mexico. The amendment would establish a proxy for the estimate of the stock maximum sustainable yield (MSY) and the rule would revise the stock annual catch limit (ACL). The the yield when fishing to a mortality rate corresponding to 30% spawning potential ratio (F30%SPR) would be the established proxy. The ACL for vermilion snapper stock would decrease for the years 2017-2021 from 3.42 million pounds whole weight to 3.11 million pounds whole weight.

Lautenberg Chemical Safety for the 21st Century Amendments to the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA), EPA is issuing a proposed rule to require reporting to assist in the preparation of an “inventory of mercury supply, use, and trade in the United States,” where “mercury” is defined as “elemental mercury” and “a mercury compound.” This proposed rule will require reporting from any person who manufactures (including imports) mercury or mercury-added products or otherwise intentionally uses mercury in a manufacturing process. text:
Comment regarding docket number 2017R-22:

Whereas similar rates of fire for semi-automatic rifles are attainable by the mere use of a belt loop on a pair of pants;

Whereas similar rates of fire for a "bump stock" can be obtained with mere practice;

Whereas the government will most likely take this rule change and extend it to any simple modification to a semi-automatic firearm, such as the replacement of a stock trigger with a trigger with less creep and a slightly lighter trigger pull;

Resolved, the suggestion of a modification to the rules currently in place is not only inappropriate but a complete waste of time, taxpayer dollars, and a further infringement on the peoples' second amendment right to keep and bear arms. Accordingly this effort should not be encouraged, followed to its conclusion, or even considered.

text:
Please enforce the United States Constitution, which is the highest law of the land, and no other law is higher. It says, "the right of the people to keep and bear arms shall not be infringed." It makes no exceptions. It does not say, "the right of the people to keep and bear arms may be infringed when the BATF believes it is a good idea." It does not even say "... if Congress thinks it's a good idea." It says, "shall not," which is just about the strongest language found anywhere in the Bill of Rights.

Now you might want to bring up some Supreme Court rulings, but I would remind you that checks and balances work three ways. Congress might make a law which is bad, and the Supreme Court might rule that the bad law is good, but the Executive Branch (that's you) get to make the decisions about enforcement. The choice about whether and how to enforce an unconstitutional law is yours.

You might also bring up the militia clause of the 2nd Amendment, which is primarily a justification clause which very concisely summarizes why the operative clause was written -- i.e. to ensure that the people are always well-equipped with milita-style weaponry, so that they can be better prepared for militia activity when called upon. (I'm sure you already know that "well-regulated" has nothing to do with rules and regulations. It means "properly functioning" and a militia can only function properly when it has the weapons necessary to do its job.) In light of the fact that one of the jobs of a militia is to repel invading armies, any weapon which would be useful to that task is therefore protected by the 2nd Amendment, regardless of what Congress or the Supreme Court says on the subject. A machine gun is certainly appropriate and protected by the 2nd, but since unconstitutional laws are already entrenched, that is no longer an issue.

The issue on the table is what to do about bump stocks. I say they are the next best thing, and they are exactly the sort of thing that the 2nd Amendment is designed to protect. The average citizen might be content to have a semi-automatic for hunting, etc., but the 2nd Amendment is not about hunting. In light of the militia clause, I believe a ban on bump stocks would be unconstitutional.
label: neg

text:
It is my intent to express concern regarding, and adamant opposition to, the ATF's intent to use their administrative power to expand the definition of rate-increasing devices on firearms to include such things as bump-stocks.

I do NOT support the ATF's current stance in considering a change of classification to any aftermarket accessory. Bump-stocks do not allow a weapon to do something that the weapon cannot inherently already do. "Bump firing" a weapon has been a behavior executed for many years and has gained popularity due to social media platforms such as YouTube and Facebook. Bump firing does not require any modification of the firearm. Bump firing does not increase the rate of fire of a civilian legal firearm to that of a Class III automatic weapon. It may mimic a higher rate of fire, but it does so utilizing unreliable means.

The action of bump firing does not in any way alter the firearm from its stock configuration or list of standard components. The "bump-stocks" only allow for an ergonomic improvement to the user during the practice of bump firing. They are not meant to increase accuracy. Nor do they increase the rate of fire of a weapon to or beyond what bump-firing without the specialized stock would account for. To consider a reclassification, or outright ban, of devices with such limited impact upon the function of a firearm opens a very expansive gray area within firearm law. It would be a mistake for the ATF to tread into this gray area without significant public input and an act of congress.

Please do NOT expand or reclassify ergonomic accessories as rate-increasing devices. As I have explained above, bump-stocks do not increase the rate of fire whatsoever beyond what a normal person may accomplish without the stock and no reclassification is necessary or warranted.
label: veryneg

text:
Wind Farms are fields of killings bats and birds, why are agencies applying laws differently?... in just four years, more than a million bats have been killed. Even though many of these bats and birds are protected by laws such as the 1918 Migratory Bird Treaty Act the ecological and economic importance of insectivorous bats in Agriculture are enormous. Renewable energy companies had enjoyed preferential treatment in the years of Obama Administration, including the ability to avoid compliance with laws. The increased development of wind-power facilities are threatening populations of insectivorous bats in North America. Bats are voracious predators of nocturnal insects, including many crop and forest pests. Loss of bats in North America could lead to agricultural losses estimated at more than $3.7 billion/year. Bats play an incredibly important role in the ecosystem, eating billions of crop-destroying insects like moths and beetles, as well as mosquitoes. But The Indiana bat is a temperate, insectivorous, migratory bat. In spring, reproductive females migrate and form maternity colonies where they bear and raise their young in wooded areas.
Bats help Farmers with impacts of PESTICIDES on ecosystems,... which can be substantial ,... or other secondary effects of predation, such as reducing the potential for evolved resistance of insects to PESTICIDES and bats help suppression of forest insects. A single colony of 150 big brown bats (Eptesicus fuscus) in Indiana has been estimated to eat nearly 1.3 million pest insects each year, possibly contributing to the disruption of population cycles of agricultural pests. Man get so much from these bats and birds by pollinating plants and spreading seeds in the ecosystems.
Example of preferential treatment Ivanpah Solar Electric Generating System project near the California and Nevada border. In addition to the clear cronyism displayed on this project, the Ivanpah Solar Electric Generating System project serves as a textbook example of how far this Administration is willing to bend over backwards for its friends at the expense of others. Owners were granted federal money to build the Ivanpah project in an area that "served as prime desert tortoise habitat," which resulted in tortoise casualties. The tortoises, which are federally listed as threatened, are not the only casualties of Ivanpah as project biologists reported the killing of 76 birds in the final three months of last year alone. In addition, the Ivanpah project had been labeled a risk to air safety due to an unsafe glare coming from the thousands of billboard-sized mirrors "nearly blinding" pilots. As if killing animals, endangering the lives of aircraft passengers, and perpetuating the revolving door of cronyism.
National mortality estimate of 573,093 birds across a total installed wind energy capacity in 2012.
Wind turbines development might be in violation Article 14, Section 4 of the New York State Constitution,
Prairie-chicken (Tympanuchus pallidicinctus), is particularly vulnerable to wind farms, it's the chicken's innate fear of looming, vertical structures that has made turbines so disastrous. Bird populations are among the fastest declining on the continent, and the turbine is the aggressor to swat native species out of existence. Low-frequency noise produced by wind turbines could interfere with the vocalizations of male prairie chickens, hens tended to move further away from any wind turbine, Wind energy is the only one that has a direct impact on birds .
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS) bird deaths from turbine collisions are between 134,000 and 327,000 birds per year. 2015 The USFWS also believed that wind energy development was an increasing threat to native bird population indicated that bird populations declined.

At the UN conference in Bonn, researchers said wind turbines and power lines were a particular problem for migratory soaring birds.
Wind Turbines and Solar panels produces huge quantities of toxic waste. The solar panels include cadmium, chromium, lead, which are toxic heavy metals that never go away. current supply production Neodymium magnets which are used as important component in large equipment that requires powerful magnetic fields, such as wind farm turbines and electric cars.
No traditional source of electric generation has ever received an open-ended, unlimited subsidy comparable to the wind and solar PTC for every kilowatt hour of energy put on the grid. Despite the billions that Congress has provided in subsidies, wind energy still produces only 6 percent of our country's electricity. Turbines only work 16 to 35 % of the time

docAbstract:
This docket is used to accept public comments that have broad applicability to the IRIS Program.  Commenters are asked to please identify themselves and provide contact information to promote an open dialogue on issues.  Examples of the types of comments appropriate for this docket include: 
•         Comments on general scientific issues that apply to all assessments
•         Other general comments (not chemical-specific) about the IRIS Program
 
The IRIS Program’s stakeholders have specifically requested this docket be created.  By having a docket for general comments, stakeholders will no longer have to submit the same general comment to individual chemical dockets that are established for each IRIS assessment.

text:
2018 Promote America oil and gas and LNG exports, and coal and mining, and Timber sales, and farming and not choose radical environmentalists over the American people. Those most hurt by Obama agencies rules and regulations were the millions of Poor and Middle class Americans who need these jobs the most. National environmental groups, that only a few years prior to Obama EPA , praised natural gas as the bridge fuel to a clean environment, but last 8 years changed to oppose . Special interest groups have largely chosen their sides between the political parties and refuse to work within reasonable bounds. Instead, they seemed to happily, if not blindly, balance on the edge of a partisan cliff while U.S. competitiveness tumbles down it. The issue of providing energy to the nation while maintaining a clean environment has become overly politicized where spin and rhetoric are preferred over facts and science. Congress should consider steering the U.S. out of the natural gas crisis and back toward a competitive and vibrant economy. It is critical that Congress act to keep American resource production from snowballing into economy-wide destruction and repeal the burdens of regulations.
Power generators expanded their demand for natural gas by 36% over the period 1997-2000. The Energy Information Administration found that between 2000 and 2003, 93 percent (187 gigawatts) of new generation capacity was gas-fired. In a June 2005 report the State of California consumed approximately 6 to 10 billion feet of natural gas per day. If California were a country, it would have ranked as the tenth largest user of natural gas worldwide. Natural gas is regarded as the cleanest burning fossil fuel and therefore should be preferred over other sources, so why is it not championed by environmental groups? Instead , they had significant and detrimental impacts on the U.S. gas and oil economy as a whole, and consumers and workers specifically.
In an industrialized and globally competitive world, energy use represents a very real and fixed cost of doing business and more fundamentally, of life. Consumers and businesses have moderated and may continue to moderate their energy use marginally, but in the end, they require energy for survival. More simply, energy is not a luxury; it is a necessity.
The Congressional Joint Economic Committee found that, "environmental laws passed in the 1980s and 1990s, and their subsequent regulations, encouraged utilities to use clean burning natural gas. during this time 90 percent of new power plants were gas-fired in large part as a result of government environmental policies. Some states' percentage of natural gas-dependent electricity was closer to 100 percent, and many of those states were starving for more natural gas. For example all of California's power plants from 1998-2005 had been natural gas-fired facilities. The U.S. have abundant natural gas resources with trillions of cubic feet , and finding more by the month. America is not running out of natural gas, and it is not running out of places to look for natural gas. America is running out of places where companies were allowed to look for gas. California's Energy Commission in 2005 report concluded that natural gas has allowed power plant developers "to meet local air quality regulations that implement the federal Clean Air Act." then the Environmental activist turned against this clean energy, makes no since.
Natural gas has been regarded as the ideal fossil fuel for multiple uses- from electricity generation to manufacturing, in part because of its efficiency, in part because of its relative cleanliness, and in part because of its relatively low delivered cost. For many years, natural gas was a wise and easy choice; America is blessed with an abundant supply and gas burns cleaner and is considered by some to be more environmentally preferable to other fuels. That abundant supply translated to low prices, and those low prices helped fuel a strong and vibrant economy. Most people probably do not realize the importance that natural gas plays in their daily lives. Natural gas is a principal feedstock to several industries including chemical and petrochemical manufacturing, the pulp and paper, steel, and fertilizer industries. The most dramatic finding was that U.S. federal laws and policies in Obama administration with regulatory burden had contributed in large measure to the nation's natural gas crisis. Federal environmental policies have prevented a sufficient and corresponding increase in supply of natural gas. These conflicting federal policies have created an artificial barrier for the market.
After quite literally placing middle income taxpayers on the brink of going out of business the government current is acknowledging the unfortunate fact -we are indeed experiencing an energy regulation crisis from the past administration.

text:
I am very disappointed by the USDA's announcement that it will withdraw the Organic Livestock and Poultry Practices rule, which sets consistent standards for animal welfare practices in organic farming." Withdrawing these standards - which organic farmers voluntarily commit to is a tremendous step backwards for the humane treatment of farm animals.

I urge the USDA to keep the organics rule in place." Animal welfare is important to end consumers, especially those that care deeply about animals.
label: veryneg

text:
I rely on the organics rule so that I can understand and feel confident in what I am purchasing. Withdrawing this takes away clear, consistent standards and is highly problematic for those of us who want to be sure we understand the ways in which animal welfare is being protected in this industry. Animal welfare is not only important as an ethical issue, but spans human, animal, and environmental health and has important considerations for One Health. Eliminating these protections is a step backwards in all of these arenas and could be catastrophic in future disease outbreaks.

Because I cannot be sure of the animal-raising practices of companies that sell products under the USDA organic label, I cannot in good conscience continue to pay premium prices for them. In turn this will harm those producers of these products and cause even wider suffering. Please reconsider withdrawing this rule.
label: veryneg

text: Withdrawing this rule, and ignoring its overwhelming support from organic producers and consumers alike, is an epic failure of public policymaking. Never in the last 27 years has USDA been confused about its authority to issue organic rules that improve the welfare of animals; its attempt to use that as an excuse to scrap this important rule threatens the integrity of the organic label and the many family farmers who rely on their customers faith in it.

text:
,

I oppose the proposed rule (RIN: 1235-AA21). It would go against decades of federal and state law and precedent safeguarding tips as the property of the workers who receive them, by allowing employers to take control of their employees tips.

The Fair Labor Standards Act was amended in 1974 to clarify that tips are to be retained by the employee except when a valid tip pooling arrangement is in place.

In 2011, the DOL issued new regulations to reinforce the FLSA and over 40 years of custom and practice by the DOL and state agencies, affirming that tips are always the property of the employee (29 C.F.R. 531.52).

If adopted, this regulation would force a vulnerable workforce further into poverty, economic instability, and vulnerability to harassment and assault.

I urge the Department of Labor to withdraw this proposed rule.

text:
The U.S. Department of Agriculture's job is to assure consumers that organically produced products meet a consistent and uniform standard. Access to outdoors means just that--access to the outdoors. I am writing today to express my strong opposition to the proposed withdrawal of the Organic Livestock and Poultry Practices final rule. I urge you to reconsider this baseless move to weaken the USDA Organic seal. This action is an assault on organic farmers, businesses, and consumers everywhere.

I rely on a strong USDA Organic seal to know that what I am purchasing is backed by a standard that I can trust. I am willing to put my money where my mouth is, but I expect products bearing the USDA Organic seal to meet rigorous standards.

It's important to me to know that the same strong standard applies to all organic products regardless of where I buy them. I understand that organic farmers and businesses of all types and sizes overwhelmingly support the final rule, and I find it outrageous that you are making this move to withdraw the rule against their recommendation. The withdrawal endorses a few businesses that deny animals access the outdoors and ignores the millions of consumers who rightly equate animals going outside with the organic label.

I want to support the organic farmers and businesses who share my values, but you are putting that in jeopardy. I urge you to please implement the final rule.
label: veryneg

text:
,

I oppose the proposed Tip Regulations Under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) regulation (RIN: 1235-AA21).

This rule would go against decades of federal and state law and precedent safeguarding tips as the property of the workers who receive them, by allowing employers to take control of their employees tips. The Fair Labor Standards Act was amended in 1974 to clarify that tips are to be retained by the employee except when a valid tip pooling arrangement is in place. In 2011, the DOL issued new regulations that reinforced the FLSA and over 40 years of custom and practice by the DOL and state agencies, affirming that tips are always the property of the employee (29 C.F.R. 531.52).

If adopted, this regulation would force a vulnerable workforce further into poverty, economic instability, and vulnerability to harassment and assault.

Personally, I tip at 20% because I believe that the fact that these workers are exempt from the minimum wage requirements that apply to almost workers is unjust. It is grossly unfair that the employers of these service workers are not required to pay proper wages to their workers.

I urge the Department of Labor to withdraw this proposed rule.

Berrien Zettler
hbzettler@charter.net
2230 Cherokee Ave, #17
Columbus, Georgia 31906
label: veryneg
docAbstract: The Department proposes to rescind portions of its tip regulations issued pursuant to the FLSA that impose restrictions on employers that pay a direct cash wage of at least the full Federal minimum wage and do not claim a tip credit against their minimum wage obligations.

docAbstract: EPA announced on September 15, 2009 the start of a rulemaking process to revise the effluent limitations guidelines and standards for the steam electric power generating point source category (i.e., steam electric power plants).  EPA’s decision to proceed with a rulemaking was made upon reviewing the findings from a multi-year study of wastewater discharges from power plants.EPA’s review of wastewater discharges from power plants, and the treatment technologies available to reduce pollutant discharges, has demonstrated the need to update the current national effluent guidelines regulations.  The current regulations, which were last updated in 1982, do not adequately address the pollutants being discharged and have not kept pace with changes that have occurred in the electric power industry over the last three decades.

text: My comments are submitted in support of the modified risk tobacco product applications: Smokers who are finding it difficult to quit should be provided with nicotine delivery alternatives that are or may be safer. The science generated by Philip Morris that I have generally seen shows that IQOS usage apparently reduces exposure to harm. Science shows that nicotine is not the main cause of smoking related diseases. Combustion is the cause. Nicotine replacement therapy provided by pharma have not appeared throughout the years to be satisfactory. While we don't know yet the long term effects of their use, private companies providing solid data should be encouraged to provide better tobacco based alternatives that are satisfactory to smokers which will encourage them to switch. I hope FDA's review will be in line with the PMI's science findings as the approval of the application will only help to achieve better public health.

text:
The Type 1 Diabetes Defense Foundation ("T1DF") welcomes the opportunity to submit comments on the Food and Drug Administration's ("FDA's") Draft Guidance. Effective implementation of the Biologics Price Competition and Innovation Act ("BPCI Act") is of importance to the individuals T1DF represents, and we greatly appreciate the FDA's efforts to provide clarity on the interplay between the new drug approval pathways under the BPCI Act and the existing approval pathways under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act ("FD&C Act").

As detailed below and in the attached filed, we do have concerns about (1) the agency's arbitrary reduction of the scope of "biological products," as defined in the Public Health Service Act ("PHS Act") and as amended by the BPCI Act, to a class solely based on the number of amino acids; (2) the resulting misclassification of glucagon as a molecule governed by the FD&C Act instead of the PHS Act; and (3) the bifurcation of approval pathways for analogous biological products, e.g. analog glucagon and analog insulin. To cure the above mentioned deficiencies, T1DF requests the following changes:

1. This Draft Guidance should be withdrawn in its entirety.

2. The definition of a biological product under 42 U.S.C. 262(i)(1), as amended by section 351(i)(1) of the PHS Act, should be clarified to include smaller molecules (less than 40 amino acids) produced via biosynthesis.
The FDA should delete from its website and documents (see footnote 1) all references to analog glucagon and analog insulin as not being biological products.

3. The FDA should issue a Draft Guidance clarifying the classification of small biosynthesized molecules, including analog glucagon, as biological products analogous to protein under 42 U.S.C. 262(i)(1), as amended by section 351(i)(1) of the PHS Act.

4. The FDA should re-issue a Draft Guidance addressing abbreviated new drug application pathways for small biosynthesized molecules under both the FD&C Act (legacy pathways until 2020) and PHS Act (biosimilar pathways).

5. The FDA should immediately investigate Eli Lilly's delay to market of Locemia Solutions intranasal glucagon spray, should make the results of its investigation public, as this is a matter of public safety and interest, and convene a new Patient Engagement Advisory Committee meeting where T1DF offers to articulate the public need for an intranasal glucagon product, particularly in the face of ongoing access barriers to injected emergency glucagon in K-12 school settings.

The Draft Guidance is presented as "assist[ing] potential applicants in determining when an application for a synthetic peptide drug product (synthetic peptide) that refers to a previously approved peptide drug product of recombinant deoxyribonucleic acid (rDNA ) origin (peptide of rDNA origin) should be submitted as an abbreviated new drug application (ANDA) under section 505(j) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FD&C Act)." But instead this Draft Guidance seems to assist potential applicants in understanding that the FDA reclassification of analog glucagon precludes the submission of an ANDA under section 505(j) of the FD&C Act, as is stated in the Draft Guidance's footnote 12.

It is T1DF's opinion that the 5 peptides subject to this Draft Guidance, glucagon, liraglutide, nesiritide, teriparatide, and teduglutide should not be subject to regulation under the FD&C Act. Instead, they should be regulated under the Public Health Service Act (PHS Act), as they meet the statutory definition of analogous biological product.

Section 351 of the PHS Act provides authority for the FDA to establish regulatory requirements for marketing biological products. The PHS Act gives precedence to consideration of production technology over molecule size when defining "biological products." The FDA has similarly emphasized production technologyand related difference in impurity profiles and thus safety approval standards and protocols.

Consistent with these interpretation standards, the 5 peptides covered by this Draft Guidance should be deemed analogous products to biosynthesized protein and should thus be defined as "biological products" within the meaning of section 351(i)(1) of the PHS Act.

It is thus T1DF's opinion that an application for a biosynthetic peptide drug product (synthetic peptide) that refers to a previously approved peptide drug product of recombinant deoxyribonucleic acid (rDNA) origin (peptide of rDNA origin) produce via biosynthesis should be submitted as a 351(k) application under the PSH Act rather than as an abbreviated new drug application (ANDA) under "section 505(j) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FD&C Act)," as suggested by this Draft Guidance. This Draft Guidance should be withdrawn.

T1DF full comment and requested changes attached (T1DF Comment - FDA Docket ID FDA-2017-D-5670 - Glucagon.pdf).

text:
October 24, 2017

The Honorable Dr. Scott Gottlieb
Administrator
Food and Drug Administration
1717 Pennsylvania Ave NW #1025
Washington, DC 20006

Dear Administrator Gottlieb,

We are pleased to respond to the Food and Drug Administration's request for comments on docket number FDA-2017-D-3001, Modified Risk Tobacco Product Applications for IQOS System.

As mothers, we believe this issue is critical to all women, particularly mothers who smoke in the home and around their children. Data shows that women are the primary caretakers of children. Therefore, helping women quit is key to improving not only their health, but also the health of their children.

We understand that children's health and safety is a priority for the FDA, particularly when it comes to exposure to cigarettes. As mothers, we appreciate the work the agency is doing to better educate teenagers about the negative health consequences of smoking. But the agency can and should do more to help mothers quit.

Sadly, for women, quitting is difficult. Multiple studies show that women have a more trouble than men quitting traditional, combustible cigarettes. Much of the difference is biology. Researchers at the University of Montreal found that women's menstruation cycle can hamper their attempt to quit traditional cigarettes. Other studies have shown women have much more severe symptoms of withdrawal and are more likely to smoke when facing stress.

When it comes to smoking cessation products, most involve simply replacing inhaled nicotine with a patch or gum. Yet, a study published in the April issue of Archives of General Psychiatry found that those nicotine replacement products don't always work for women. This is significant because, currently, the FDA only approves these nicotine replacement therapies to help people quit smoking. Clearly, women need additional options, such as products that help replace other cravings and behaviorslike the taste and smell of traditional cigarettes and the hand-to-mouth habits associated with smoking.

FDA needs to recognize the gender differences between men and women and they need to understand that providing women more choices in the marketplace isn't just a women's health issue, it's a children's health issue too. As such, we urge the FDA to expand the product choices in the marketplace and approve innovative products, like the IQOS e-cigarette.

Sincerely,

Stacie Rumenap
President, Stop Child Predators and mother of three

Julie Gunlock
Writer and mother of three
label: pos
